question_text:
Vickers notes that cancer is largely the result of mutation.
She also notes that by the time one finishes growing, essentially all of one’s cells will have at least some mutated DNA.
Given this is the case, why aren’t we all plagued by cancer by the time we reach adulthood?
neutral_comments: While cancer is the result of mutations and all cells harbor mutations, it does not logically follow that all cells will be cancerous. It’s not just the fact that cells harbor mutations that make the cancerous, as Vicker notes, it’s the nature of these mutations (how extensive are the mutations, where do they occur, and how do they alter the behavior of a cell) that also matter.

question_text:
Of the Hallmarks of Cancer (HoC) listed, which of them are related to

a. Inappropriate cell division?

b. Inappropriate cell survival?
neutral_comments:
a. HoC 1) They can tell themselves to multiply, HoC 2) They are insensitive to negative feedback which would normally tell them to stop multiplying, HoC 4) Unlimited replicative ability. Once could also include HoC 5) and 7) as being indirectly related to inappropriate cell division.

b. HoC 2) They are insensitive to negative feedback that would normally trigger apoptosis (programmed cell death), 3) They resist normal cell death [that would occur in the absence of any negative feedback in HoC 2)]. HoC 8) They can avoid destruction by the immune system.

question_text:
Vickers provides multiple ways cancer is challenging to treat. Briefly describe two of these ways to a relative who is wondering why scientists haven’t found a cure for cancer yet.

a)

b)

The human haploid genome (i.e. what we would find in sperm and eggs) consists of approximately 3×109 base pairs (bp).

a. Convert this number from scientific notation to the ‘normal’ way we right numbers. (i.e. 102 would be 100, 103 would be 1,000, ....)

b. Convert this number into a verbal description. (i.e. 102 would be one hundred, 103 would be one thousand)

c. Using scientific notation and the information provided in Brooker (2019) Figure 12.6, give the typical range of sizes of eukaryotic chromosomes in bp.
neutral_comments:
a) 3×109=3,000,000,000 base pairs.

b) 3×109 = Three billion base pairs.

c) 10’s of millions = 107 and 100’s of millions = 108

question_text:
This question has three parts.

a) Which category of DNA is most of the human genome found and what does it primarily consist of?

b) How does the amount of DNA in this category compare to the amount of DNA in the category of protein coding sequences?

c) Do you find these facts surprising? Explain your answer.
neutral_comments:
a) The vast majority of the human DNA consists of (highly) repetitive sequences consisting primarily of parasitic DNA known as transposable elements and tandem arrays?

b) There is about 30 times more repetitive DNA than protein codong DNA.

c) Most people find this surprising because it suggests that most of the human genome is non-adaptive or junk.

question_text:
Define and explain the relationship between the following terms related to DNA packaging in the genome

a. Histones b. Nucleosome c. Chromatin
neutral_comments: Histones are a class of proteins involved in the packaging of DNA at the smallest scale. DNA is wrapped around an octomer of histones which, together, make up an nucleosome. The nucleosome can be stabilized by additional linker histones. Histones and DNA are two of the main components of the chromatin found in the cell nucleus.

question_text:
According to Doolittle and Brunet (2017), function in biological systems can be defined in multiple ways.

a. Define and differentiate between causal role definition of function and the selected effect definition of function.

b. Identify and explain which different fields of biology implicitly adopt a CR vs SE definition of functionality.

c. How does your answer to the previous question help explain the controversy surrounding the ENCODE consortium’s claim that 80% of the human genome is ‘functional’ because it is transcriptionally active or bound by transcription factors?
neutral_comments:
a. The causal role (CR) definition of function assigns functionality to any component of a biological system that contributes to a given process, regardless of whether it has an affect on an organism’s fitness. The selected effect (SE) definition, by contrast, defines function based on whether a trait has been maintained by natural selection for a particular effect. Thus, under the CR definition, transcriptional activity alone may be considered “functional,” whereas under the SE defintion, if the transcriptional activity has no effect on an organisms fitness is it is considered “non-functional” noise.

b. Different biological disciplines tend to emphasize one definition over the other based on their methodologies and objectives:

For example, Molecular and Cellular Biology often employs the causal role (CR) definition, as these fields focus on identifying biochemical interactions, transcriptional activity, and molecular mechanisms. In these contexts, a DNA sequence or protein is often considered “functional” if it has an observable effect on cellular processes, regardless of its impact on fitness or evolutionary history.

In contrast, Evolutionary Biology and Comparative Genomics predominantly use the selected effect (SE) definition, as these fields work to understand the role of natural selection has, if any, in shaping traits over time.

c. The controversy stems from ENCODE’s use of the causal role (CR) definition, which considers biochemical activity (e.g., transcription, protein binding) as evidence of function. This led to the claim that 80% of the genome is functional.

Evolutionary biologists, using the selected effect (SE) definition, argue that most of this activity is nonadaptive and that only ~10% of the genome shows evidence of selection. The lungfish and onion genomes, which are much larger than the human genome without increased complexity, further challenge the idea that most non-coding DNA is functional in the SE sense.

Thus, the debate is not about whether non-coding DNA is active, but whether such activity has evolutionary significance.

question_text:
Doolittle and Brunet (2017) argue that genome size variation among organisms, such as the lungfish and onion, provides strong evidence against the claim that most of the human genome is functional under the selected effect (SE) definition.

How does the existence of these (and manyother organisms) organisms with much larger genomes challenge the idea that the majority of the human genome has been maintained by natural selection for specific functions?
neutral_comments:
Organisms like lungfish and onions have genomes many times larger than the human genome without a corresponding increase in complexity. If most of the human genome were functional under the selected effect (SE) definition, then these organisms should have even greater functional complexity, which is not observed.

Instead, their large, primarily non-coding genomes are likely the result of evolutionary processes other than adaptation (such as replication of TEs or the evolution of polyploidy). As a corollary, it follows that most of the human (which is also primarily non-coding DNA) is also likely the result of non-adaptive evolutionary processes. This challenges the claim that most of the human genome has a selected function.
